comments.commentBody:
My thought exactly, Barry.

Potrezebie.
I found some old Mad Magazines several years back.  If those had folded top to bottom I may have had a chance getting the theme today.
It's crackers to slip a rozzer the dropsy in snide!
I attribute a quick grasp of the theme to a youth spent with Mad magazine.

.
Take the top 50% off the characters, reading only what remains.

The bottom of T = I
The bottom of B = D
The bottom of 8 = o
The bottom of L = L with different proportions. Hence, IDOL.
Ahhhhhhhhh ... THAT bottom! The wrong side of my brain must have been working while the right side was napping. Many many thanks from a relative beginner!

Thanks for stepping in to help Angelika, MTF!

Angelika, welcome to Wordplay and please join us. We all started out as relative beginners, but there is a terrific community here to pull you along. Keep on solving!

Y'all,
Call me a sap, call me a sponge, call me a zero ... but I still don't get it. I solved the puzzle, however I still have no clue where and how I should find vivid or ovoid or idol, or what the connection to the puzzle is. TB8L = IDOL? Huh?

Silly me!

.
Agree on shells exploding and bullets not exploding but --

If a BULLET did have a DEFECT such that it did not propel out of the barrel as expected, what would you call it if not a "Dud"? (Same question for a bomb with an internal propulsive charge, which fails to explode.)
Just terrible, but Erdogan has been playing with fire with Daesh for quite some time. Time for a serious reevaluation of the direction he has taken his country.

Driving 2 hrs to a specific location where gays, not exclusively but primarily, congregate is a fact, not an opinion. If you live in a world, or possess a mindset, wherein you consider the discussion of facts to be "peddling" or somehow pushing an agenda, then what exactly do you deem an opinion?  Just because a fact doesn't fit a someone's specific religious or heteronormative world view, doesn't make the fact any less true. It appears that for some readers, the fact that the massacre could be motivated by both radical Islam and homophobia is untenable. In reality, one begets the other. Islam preaches, and Islamic states carry out, the execution of gays. That is a fact.
And I might add that it was a fine caliber debut puzzle; not a bore.

and Elke

RMP- did you consider recusing yourself ? :))
Watch out for SURGES after power outages.

That analysis is not nearly as astute as it thinks it is.

While yes, it's true that Boris would be a lot more comfortable if Cameron had begun the process already, I see no reason to suppose that he'll flinch from doing the deed himself when he gets the chance. The entire argument why he "should" do so boils down to "because it'll be a disaster", which basically begs the entire question.

Then why not let men compete in women's events?  The reality is people win athletic events primarily because of genetics, training and drugs, and people with the right genetics tend to respond better to training and drugs.  That someone can run  400 meters faster than another person really has little meaning.  So the idea of paying a lot of attention to who wins an athletic cost  is primarily watching who has the genetics for the event.  Just trying won't do it.  So on the average men will win a lot of events preferentially over women because of their genetics.  If we segregate athletics into medically or culturally defined sex, gender or whatever you want to call it you are again primarily looking at who has the best genetics. in that subgroup.
Actually we do. Check with Floyd Landis, for example.

Gender testing is ridiculous. Like the article pointed out, it seems incredibly unfair to be barring certain women because of their supposed unfair advantage due to elevated testosterone levels, while we don't even check to see if high-performing men have abnormally high testosterone levels, which should be equally unfair to other men. I support categorizing based on self-identification. If a person is raised and lives as a female, they can compete as a female. No men in disguise have ever been caught so far, and besides, the playing field is already completely unequal: there are a myriad other factors that contribute to an athlete's success, such as lung capacity, muscle fiber composition, nutrition, parental involvement, and training, to name a few.

"Isn't the whole point of the Olympics to celebrate humanity's strength and build comradery among nations? "

That's more than a trifle naive. If it were so, the athletes would not march in under national flags, and winner's would not weep as their nation's flag was raised and its national anthem played.

The Olympics are about winning and getting your face on the Wheaties box.

It doesn't improve performance in a male with testicular feminization, now referred to as androgen insensitivity syndrome.  These people are phenotypic females who have undescended testes and normally have the genitalia and body structure of genetic females, but they are medically classified as males. Many live to adulthood thinking they are female.
Wait a minute, the Olympics are largely white and rich? Im sure the Nigerian delegation would beg to differ.

The only international sports competition worth following is the Paralymics -- they should get rid of the Olympics entirely.

I would much rather watch athletes overcome their disabilities and the disadvantages they are confronted with than a bunch of largely rich, white 'athletes' -- born with the dumb luck of being statistical physical outliers, obsessed with cheating the system in order to land sportswear modeling contracts.

Women have enough equality problems without letting men compete against them in sports.  What about transgendered men who become women with men's muscles and hormones?  Many say Serena Williams had such an operation as a young girl, which would explain her super manly physique.  Tennis doesn't conduct gender tests.

I agree.  This article infuriated me and broke my heart at the same time.  Why, why, why does this prejudice continue?  Why does ignorance trump (!) scientific inquiry?  If science doesn't know, why are those "in charge" so certain of their draconian decisions?  Human beings are wonderfully made.  That wonder needs to be honored, not disdained.
It would certainly cut down on instances of athletes committing acts of domestic violence.

Human sexuality is not a continuum from a biological or medical standpoint.  Sex is determined by the presence of ovaries or testes.  A person may appear externally totally female but possess undescended testes and are insensitive to androgens, they are males.  A person with ovaries is female, A person with both ovaries and testes is a hermaphrodite, which although rare does occur.
I quite sympathize with the notion that intersex athletes have an inborn advantage when they compete against women. At the same time I wonder if tall players should be banned from basketball.

What "looks masculine" and "looks feminine"  is not an objective opinion, but determined by cultural bias , which in our cultural is largely determined  by advertising. The multi-billion dollar cosmetic industry sells products to females to alter every inch of their body in order to look "feminine". For example, women in North America shave their legs, armpits and upper lip to "look feminine", but women in some European cultures do not have to shave their body hair to be considered "feminine".  Similarly, having a strong, muscular physique has nothing to do with what is is biologically natural for women, but everything to do with convincing women that they should look soft and weak to be "feminine". A woman can stop menstruating temporarily for a variety of reasons and that is natural too since her body is not designed to give birth continuously from puberty to menopause. And who says that giving birth is not "heavy work"? It requires more physical stamina and endurance than running a 100 yard dash!

biological definition of sex is determined by the presence of ovaries and testes which is almost always determined by sex chromosones, the issue is a bit more complicated than XX or XY, but is too complex to discuss here.
No, it means that they are not the elite athletes on the scale of female competitors that they appeared to be.

When they tell them they can't compete with the women, are they allowed to compete with the men? Because they should be. Or would they be laughably below the qualification standards for the men's races? If they would be laughably beneath the standards for men, then probably they aren't men, right?
What an odd idea. Anthony had quite large breasts. Elizabeth Cady Stanton had 7 children. Most were married with kids.
A handful of strange and bizarre people do not have any real bearing on the rest of us.

Strike a blow for equal rights for all. Do away with sex division in sports. No WNBA, LPGA. One division in the Olympics.

And 95% of the medals will be won by men. There will be almost no women in the combined NBA.

Not fair? Then put up with testing. If you let people self-declare, then some men will self-declare just to get an easier path to a gold medal.

Border conditions like intersex are always difficult. But, unless you want (mostly) men winners, you have to have some kind of rules.

MTF, I will confess to a raised eyebrow at your note that the author had used the word COLORED in his text, so I read it. I agree it's an unfortunate choice of words but not quite what I feared.

As to your other point, Wikipedia does say that he 'earned' them. I would tend to go with 'earned' for the Bronze star and 'received' for the Purple Heart, as the latter is largely the 'luck of the draw' so to speak.

Actually had a discussion with two friends on this very subject within the last month and have also have talked with a former officer about the medal thing in the past. The officer once explained to me that deciding that a soldier deserves a medal and writing a citation that will actually get approved are two entirely different matters, and he noted that the majority of his submissions were rejected or sent back with suggestions for re-wording.

In discussions with my friends, I was surprised to learn that we all tended to regard certain medals as, essentially, lifetime achievement awards even though they are always actually awarded for a specific incident. I think that reflects the officer's dilemma in some respects.

Lastly, we all agreed that on the telegram home one is always 'slightly' wounded but that on the medal citation one is always 'seriously' wounded. See above.

Oh, and from what I read, I think Rangel definitely earned at least a Silver Star, even though he received the Bronze.

I can't get the Roll Call article to load--it just keeps sprocketing--so I'm not sure how the word COLORED was used.

I guess anyone who had been in the job as long as he had would have both high and low points, and he had more than his share of both. (See career of his predecessor.) I also think he should have called it a career a bit earlier than he did, before some of the lows caught up with him.

I'm not in that district, but I've certainly enjoyed watching the nine-person (I think) competition for his seat. And I'm looking forward to see what happens next.

.
Saved my off-topic text for a separate comment so an EMU can remove it without disturbing my remarks about the solve:

It's nomination season around the country. My Congressional Representative is retiring after almost a half-century in the House, so the parties nominated non-incumbents. A Washington publication that is distributed gratis on Capitol Hill ran this article about the District and its departing incumbent:

http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/espaillat-declares-victory-charlie...

If anyone clicks that and reads the penultimate paragraph, I wonder if they could confirm/refute my opinion that there are 2 unfortunately-chosen words in its 3 lines.

1. It says he "received" a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart. Having read prior Comments, I take the stance that he "earned" those decorations when -- during fighting in the Korean conflict that preceded the current Armistice -- he led his men to safety after they had been encircled by (mainland) Chinese troops. [As far as I know, he is the last remaining member of the House who participated in combat in Korea in the 50s.]

2. The writer uses the same word that follows BRIGHTLY in today's grid. The man in question has indeed had a checkered history in the House. He was censured for ethics violations; but he also co-founded the Congressional Black Caucus.

-----

Elsewhere, transgendered persons won nominations for a House seat from Colo. and a Senate seat from Utah. Those are believed to be "firsts".
